Award.AwardTitle: Postdoctoral Fellowship: The Impact of Big Data on the Science of Metabolism

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the direction of Hannah Landecker, post-doctoral scholar Nadine Levine, will carry out a two year laboratory ethnography focusing on the impact of big data on the science of metabolism. This study of metabolomics, the post-genomic study of the molecules and processes that make up metabolism, will serve as a case study for the role and impact of big data in biomedical research.


The findings of this project will contribute to science policy discussions on the key opportunities and challenges facing the increasingly prominent field of metabolomics, as well as other fields of data-intensive research. Moreover, the findings of this project will provide collaborative and educational resources, which will enable students, researchers, and members of the public to understand how,and with what consequences for the diagnosis and treatment of disease, new understandings of metabolism are being generated with big data.

Performance_Institution.Name: Institute for Society and Genetics, UCLA

ProgramReference.Text: SOC STUDIES OF SCI, ENG & TECH

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Overview

21st century humans are obsessed with data: with collecting, analyzing, and testing the limits of what it can do and say. Invocations to the power and value of data are ubiquitous in contemporary biomedicine, as research is increasingly carried out with computerized tools and databases, and as knowledge about bodies and populations is generated through the management and interpretation of large data sets. We are at a moment in time where data seems central to understandings of and interventions into disease, through fields like genomics and epigenetics, and through paradigms like translational research and precision medicine. And yet, data’s practices, questions, and effects on society are far from settled.

This project examined how so-called “big data” intersects with biomedical research to give rise to new ways of understanding and intervening into metabolism. It focused on metabolomics, the post-genomic study of the molecules and processes that make up metabolism. In this evolving field, much everyday work is devoted to understanding data--type, format, size, scale, and meaning—as well as metabolism—chronic conditions like diabetes and cancer, the division between organisms and their environment. Metabolomics, because it exists at the nexus of data-intensive research and chronic disease interventions, makes for an excellent case study to explore how data’s practices, questions, and effects on society are far from settled.

For this project, I carried out interviews and ethnographic research at two institutions: the European Bioinformatics Institute in the United Kingdom, and The Scripps Research Institute in San Diego California. In the field of metabolomics, researchers are constantly developing new computational tools, new ways of processing and cleaning data, new ways of organizing and standardizing it into tables and databases, and new ways of analyzing and interpreting it with algorithms and statistics.
I drew on interviews, observations, and analyses of published literature to examine the statistical, software, and database tools that researchers use to quantify health metabolism, and also the challenges researchers encounter as they try to translate the resulting “big” biomedical data into health interventions.

The resulting research from this project questions the widespread assumption that “more data is better,” or that data is more objective than other forms of expertise. It shows how various kinds of expertise and politics are wrapped up in data-intensive science, as researchers produce post-genomic metrics for evaluating, measuring, and intervening into bodies and populations. Examining how data is negotiated at the laboratory-clinic interface, the project shows that big data produces normative understandings of individual and population health, and struggles to capture the holistic dimensions of health and well-being.

Outcomes

The main output of this project was a book manuscript titled Metabolizing Data, which combines this research with related doctoral research conducted at Imperial College London in the United Kingdom. In addition, this research resulted in a number of conference presentations, as well as several co-authored scientific papers.

Intellectual Merits & Broader Impacts

Drawing on the data collected in this project, I created a framework for the “anthropology of data”: an agenda for examining the norms and politics embedded within data, which are immaterial and transient and yet affect society in profound ways. Methodologically, this project advanced the long-standing field of laboratory studies, by demonstrating what it looks and feels like to do an ethnography of big data: to do anthropology where the vast majority of work is done at computer screens, in which researchers are working with algorithms and visualizations rather than physical materials. This project also contributed to scholarship at the nexus of anthropology and science and technology studies (STS), by opening up the black box of big data and statistics. This project shed light on the computational and statistical techniques and technologies that biomedical researchers use to create knowledge about diseases and populations, and which more broadly shape contemporary society’s quantitative and informational view of life.  

 


Last Modified: 04/19/2017
Modified by: Hannah L Landecker
